transformed_texts:
You know, I feel like the Catholic Church needs to update some of its ideas.  

A lot of people are saying the Church is losing followers, and I think it's because they're not very open-minded about things like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. The Church has strong beliefs on these issues, which is fine, but they seem a bit stuck in the past.

If they were more open to modern thinking, I think they wouldn't worry so much about losing people. I've heard that some folks are turning away from the Church because they disagree with its stance on these topics. They feel like the Church is wrong about these things.

For example, if you believe in abortion rights, you might not feel comfortable in a place where it's seen as completely wrong.  Same goes for gay marriage - if you support that, you might not want to be part of a group that doesn't.

I don't see why they can't have female priests or why priests can't be married. But I'm not sure if that would have stopped the scandals we've seen. It's hard to say for sure if things would be different.


It just seems unfair that priests are expected to be completely devoted to God while everyone else gets to have a family and other relationships.

Ehm...you know, I'm okay with gay marriage.  I don't think it's something you choose, like it's just how you are, ya know?  I don't think we should blame people for being gay. So, it feels wrong to say that a man and woman can marry, but two people of the same sex can't. It just doesn't seem fair.

Honestly, I haven't thought about this too much, but I feel like it's wrong to say that. It's not like someone decides to be gay, right?  Just like I was born straight, someone else might be born gay.  It's not a choice.

(clears throat) Yeah, I think it's wrong to stop people from getting married just because they're the same gender.

I don't think the government should get involved, because it's not really a legal issue or something they should decide. It's more of a personal thing.  I don't want it to feel like we're putting gay people on display or making them feel like they made a mistake.

So I don't think the government should have anything to say about it. It's just not their place.

It's kind of complicated, you know?

(laughs)

I guess I don't think the government should be involved because it doesn't affect national security or anything like that. It's not a moral issue. It's just about people's lives and who they love.

It just feels wrong to me to tell people they can't marry because of who they are. It's like how they were born, and they shouldn't be punished for it.

Okay, here's the thing about gay marriage.  There's really no good reason not to allow it.  Some folks think that same-sex couples are a threat to families, but that's just not true. It's like comparing apples and oranges - they're different but both are fruit.  It comes down to basic rights, like health care and property.  If you're in a gay relationship, your partner might not be able to be with you in the hospital or make medical decisions if you're sick. It's messed up if you're committed to someone and they can't be there for you when you need them. Studies show that gay couples are just as happy and successful as straight couples. It's about love and commitment, not anything else.  

What really bothers me is that people get hung up on the religious angle. Gay couples aren't asking for a church wedding, they just want a legal marriage certificate. Keep religion and government separate, right? It's like saying someone can't get married because their religion doesn't approve - that's not fair.  

People worry about adoption and how kids will turn out, but there's no proof that kids raised by gay parents are any different.  It's about good parenting, not who the parents are. In some places, kids from gay families get bullied just for being different. That's wrong.

We need the government to step up and make gay marriage legal everywhere. It's about equality and treating everyone fairly. [

Okay, so here's the thing about working at a hospital pharmacy during the summer.  Just because something's illegal doesn't mean it can't be helpful.  I mean, I get it, making it freely available to everyone? Big no-no. But for medical reasons? Definitely yes.  I mean,  illegal doesn't equal no good, right?  

Think about it, pharmacies use all sorts of controlled substances like Oxycontin, Vicodin, Percocet -  things that are totally illegal for regular folks. But doctors use them all the time because they can help people.  It's just that there's this crazy stigma around marijuana. We shouldn't judge something just because it's illegal. 

Alcohol is a good example, too.  It's legal but can be awful if you abuse it.  Marijuana can be abused too, but it's not as bad.  Maybe we should start slow with marijuana, make it legal gradually.  First, we need to ditch the bad image we have of it.  If we can get people to see it as something that can be used responsibly, then things might change. 

People think marijuana is super dangerous just because it's illegal, but it's not like heroin or cocaine.  If we stop thinking of it as this horrible drug, people might be more willing to use it responsibly, especially for medical reasons.

So, yeah, I think the church has definitely changed with the times. It's not as strict as it used to be, you know? When I was a kid, every Sunday I'd go to church, all dressed up in cute dresses and matching shoes and purses, the whole nine yards. I went to a private school, so I'd see all my friends there on Sundays too. But now that I'm older, they have this teenager mass, and it's only thirty minutes long! People dress way more casually now, especially in the summer. You see people coming straight from the beach in their swimsuits, families rushing in late, the whole deal. Even at the morning masses, where I used to always dress up, people are now wearing jeans and khakis. It's a lot more relaxed overall. 

That's the biggest thing I've noticed about the changes. As for other stuff, I don't really know much about the inner workings of the church, but that's the church I know.


Regarding all those accusations against Catholic priests about pedophilia, I don't think allowing female priests or letting priests get married would have stopped it.  After all, there are married men who still become pedophiles. It's not about being married or not, it's about the person.  It's their choice to become a priest, and some religions allow priests to be married, like in that show "Seventh Heaven."  If they really want to marry and practice their faith, maybe they should consider a different religion.

I think pedophilia might be based on genetics,  something you're born with. You can't just change that by getting married. It might come out eventually, even if they try to hide it.  I don't think the church could have prevented this from happening. If they knew about it and tried to cover it up, shame on them. But I don't think they always knew.

(laughs)
So, you see, at first I was okay with the whole situation, but everyone was still pretty shaken up after 9/11. I think we went into Iraq under false pretenses. The Bush administration, they linked the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and 9/11 right away, saying Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction.  We know now that none of that was true. It really bothers me that they led people astray like that.  Honestly, the Iraq war just makes my blood boil.

It feels like the Bush administration straight-up lied to the American people and they haven't even admitted it yet.  Even Colin Powell, after his big speech at the UN, admitted he wasn't really convinced by the evidence back then!  That's just wrong, plain and simple. To me, that's a serious offense. They don't seem to care about the Constitution at all, not since 9/11 anyway.  It seems like they came into office wanting to go to war.

I read in this book by a former Treasury Secretary – I can't remember his name – that the younger Bush was basically out for revenge against Saddam Hussein because of his dad's administration. Plus, he probably wanted to control more of the world's energy supply.  That's a pretty sneaky way to do things.

It's been going on for far too long. Pulling out right now would be messy, though.  The country could easily fall into civil war and even more people would die.

So, the UN and the US are trying to get other countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia involved to help fix things. But I'm not sure that's a good idea either.  It could lead to even more problems down the road because Iraq's sovereignty would become a huge issue.  The current government is falling apart, and the Parliament isn't doing much to help.  The Prime Minister doesn't really have any power, and even that guy, Mugtada al-Sadr, who we were fighting not too long ago, has a bunch of seats in Parliament now.  There are a lot of different groups fighting for control, and it's causing a lot of trouble.

(laughs)

I could go on, but it's probably best not to say it all out loud.

Mmm hmm. Let me just talk about my thoughts on the war in Iraq. Honestly, I feel like it’s kind of pointless. It wasn't even officially declared a war, you know? It feels like it was just a way for us to retaliate against Iraq because they were suspected of being behind the 9/11 attacks.  

I'm not really into following all the details of the war, but it seems like we're still there trying to establish a democracy, kind of like making Iraq another U.S. ally, and maybe also to secure their oil. But staying there just keeps causing more problems and making people upset. 

Plus, building a democracy takes a long time. It's not something you can just force overnight. If we leave suddenly, they'll be angry because they'll feel like we messed everything up and left them to deal with the mess. It's a real dilemma.

Honestly, this topic is really hard for me. I don't know that much about it. I guess I feel torn. On one hand, I want the war to end because it's causing so much suffering. There are so many families with loved ones in Iraq, and I worry about them.  

But on the other hand, I don't want to leave Iraq in a worse state. It seems like our involvement has already caused a lot of chaos, and trying to force our way of life on them could make things even worse. I worry that it will just fuel more resentment and violence.


I think this whole situation is going to drag on for a long time, and it's really sad.

Hmm... this whole issue about making it legal, it just feels wrong, you know? Like, it shouldn't be up to the government to decide. Our constitution, it clearly says separation of church and state.  It's written right there. Trying to force this on everyone, it feels like going against what's already been decided.  Plus, it seems like people pushing to make it illegal are just favoring one church's beliefs over others.  I mean, most Catholics and Christians aren't on board with it, except maybe in some places like Boston. But it shouldn't be up to the government to tell churches what they can and can't do.

Separation of church and state is super important, it's what makes religious freedom possible in the US. Even though they talked about making an amendment, I think that's a bad idea. It would go against what's already in the constitution and would probably be the only amendment that restricts people instead of the government. 

Honestly, I don't think the federal government should have anything to do with this.  I don't get why someone would push for this amendment unless it's just because of their own personal beliefs as a Catholic. It seems like they're trying to push their religion over everyone else's.  It should be up to the churches to decide, not the president or anyone else in government.  There's no good reason for an amendment banning it, it wouldn't even impact the economy or anything like that.  It might even help society in some ways.

Okay, so, about the war in Iraq... I don't really believe the government was completely honest with the people about why we went to war. They tried to connect it to the 9/11 attacks, even though those two things weren't really related. The government used the fear and anger from 9/11 to push for the invasion, which started in 2003. 

Personally, I'm against war, especially starting one without a good reason.  This war feels a lot like Vietnam – we made the same mistakes.  So many American soldiers have died, and it's heartbreaking. The US just kicked out Iraq's government without a plan for what would happen next, which created chaos. 

They wanted to put in a democracy, just like in Vietnam, but it's a really difficult and long process. It wasn't a clear victory like they made it seem. It's more like a loss because there are always going to be people who resist, even if they want change. 

I think the government wasn't prepared for the consequences of removing the Iraqi government.  We're still there, and it's almost 2007, yet we're still losing soldiers. We're trying to train Iraqi troops, but it's taking forever. The US government didn't seem to understand how long and hard it takes to establish a new government. 

It's complicated. We went in there, and now it's hard to just leave. We took away their government and way of life, so what do we do now? It's a tough choice. We risk more American lives for a democratic Iraq, but how many is too many? 

Why are we focusing on Iraq and not other countries that need this kind of change? I think it might be about the oil.  Remember, they said Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but we never found any. North Korea has those weapons, but we're not doing anything about it.  I don't think the US government is being truthful about its reasons for going to war.

I just hope it ends soon and there's peace in Iraq, but I'm not sure that will happen.

Hmm...let me see... I'm all for gay marriage, always have been.  I truly believe it's a personal choice, you know? And studies show it's more about biology than anything else.  It's not fair to take away someone's rights because of something they can't control. It feels wrong, you know? 

I've always been a supporter of gay marriage. Politics and the government shouldn't have a say in this. It's a personal matter, something between two people.  Like in my neighborhood, there are a couple of openly gay couples who aren't married because the law won't let them. But they live their lives just like any other family, walking their dogs and doing normal things. 

It's crazy how some people, like Bush, try to play God and decide what marriage means.  I think it's ridiculous. 

There's tons of research showing that being gay is a biological thing, something you're born with. It's not a choice.

The thing is, if a guy and a girl want to get married they can just elope to Vegas and do it secretly. But if two gay people want to get married, it becomes a big public scandal. It shouldn't be a big deal, you know? It should be a private matter, not something the government gets involved in.

Sharing things online is like putting them out in a public square, everyone can see it. It's not private. As someone who works with people, I've seen this firsthand. What you post online can shape how people view you. If you're talking about violent things, someone might get worried. You can't just put anything out there.

The internet is huge, anyone can see it. If you're friends with someone on Myspace, you'll get their updates. So, if someone sees something concerning online, they might tell the school. They can't ignore it, because if something bad happens, they might have been able to stop it.

It's tricky though, because sometimes people joke around online, and it's hard to know what's serious. It could be a harmless experiment gone wrong, or it could be a real threat. In one case, someone overheard something in school and told the school. They looked at the student's Facebook and found some posts that seemed harmless, but in light of the situation, they were worrisome.

Basically, once you put something online, it's out there. If you don't want people to see it, don't post it. You can't control what people think or how they interpret it.

I don't think school officials should be friends with their students on social media and snooping through their profiles. But if someone brings something to their attention, it's not an invasion of privacy because the person shared it publicly. They have to take it seriously if there's a potential danger.

This war feels like it's been going on forever.  In the beginning, I understood the goal – to bring democracy to a country that needed it. But somewhere along the way, I think we lost sight of that.  Now it feels like we're just fighting for the sake of fighting, trying to prove something to the world.  

I even wonder if the reasons for starting the war were a bit shaky to begin with. There were those old issues between George Bush's dad and Saddam Hussein, and I can't help but think they played a part.

If the goal truly was to help people gain a fair political system, that would be a good reason for war. But if there were personal vendettas involved, then it wouldn't be right.

Anyway, the war dragged on for way too long.  We made our point in the first few months, but now it just feels endless.

I mean, if our goal was to free people from a tyrannical leader, that's a worthy cause. But over time, I think our reasons have gotten muddled. It feels like we're just stuck in a cycle of fighting, needing to declare victory, even if we've lost sight of what we're fighting for. 

This war needs to end.  At some point, those people have to take responsibility for their own country. We've been pouring billions of dollars into this conflict, money that could be used to help our own people. We have so many problems here at home – poverty, education, healthcare – that deserve our attention.

It's just not right to keep spending so much money on a war that has lost its purpose.

Let me ask, though, isn't it kind of okay that someone found that information online?  Like, wasn't it good that someone saw it and was able to stop something bad from happening?

I mean, it's tricky, right? You can't have someone watching every single student's profile all the time. It would be unfair to pick on certain kids and snoop on them just because they might be up to something.  

But, I guess it depends on the situation. Was someone just randomly looking, or were they looking for specific things? 

It's similar to how I feel about my own social media. I have Facebook, and it's scary to think about how much information is out there and how people can find it. I've heard stories about creeps who can easily get your information and even get you to meet up with them. It makes me nervous because they can learn a lot about you from your profile – your interests, your friends, even your schedule.

I try to be careful about what I share, but it's hard because I also want to connect with my friends.

It's a tough balance. It's weird to think about schools banning Myspace, though. How can they really control what their students do online?  It feels like an invasion of privacy, even if they think they're trying to protect us.

Hmm... Okay, so there's this thing about the Iraq War that I kinda feel weird talking about. I hate to sound like everyone else who's all, "I knew it was a bad idea from the start!"  But, honestly, it's just...  It feels like everyone agrees it was a mess except for the people in charge, who don't want to admit they were wrong. You see it everywhere.  Poll after poll, people from the US, Iraq, even around the world, say it was a bad call.  Seventy-five to eighty percent think we should have never gone there. Even a lot of our own soldiers feel that way!

It's been a total disaster from the beginning.  And getting out is going to be another disaster. Honestly, it feels like anything we do in the Middle East just turns into a nightmare.

It's like we don't get it.  The US and the Middle East, we're just too different.  This administration, and the ones before it, think they can just force democracy on a place that isn't ready for it. It's not how things work there.

Sure, Saddam Hussein was a bad guy, but invading a country without thinking about all the consequences is just reckless. It's like falling into quicksand.

I don't know what to say about it anymore. I don't see any reason to stay. I'm sure the government has some fancy reasons for staying, but I haven't heard anything convincing.

If they want to leave gradually, maybe over a year, I wouldn't mind. But leaving now would be the best.

I read that eighty percent of Iraqis want us gone within a year, and some even want us to leave right now. Those are the people we're trying to help!  Maybe they know what's best for them. If we ask them and they say leave, at least we can say we tried to do what they wanted.

Maybe then, if things go bad, we can step in and actually be the good guys.  I mean, we're never going to be totally loved in the Middle East, but at least it would be better than where we are now.

Um, yeah, I totally think gender discrimination is still a thing in the US.  It's not just about women though. It seems to depend on what kind of work you do.  I mean, overall, I feel like women have it tougher because there's this invisible ceiling, even though equality is supposed to be a thing.  Lots of guys struggle with the idea of working under a woman because of how society has always been. So, women often see jobs they're totally qualified for, but the board might not choose them because historically, women haven't been in those top business roles.  And, it's kind of the same for men too. Like, in fields like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent, it's not really common to see a man doing those things. People often judge them for it, thinking a man should be working and making money for the family. It can be really hard on them, especially if it's always been their dream to stay home with the kids and help out, even if the wife has the better job.  It just works for them, but society doesn't get it.  And in fashion, sometimes people don't take men seriously if they're straight. I don't know if that makes sense, but maybe it's because guys who are into fashion are often seen as having different lifestyles.  So if a guy has a typical lifestyle and he's in fashion, people might think, "How can you really know about fashion if you're not a woman?"  It's like they don't think he understands women's fashion.  

So, depending on the field, I definitely feel like there's gender discrimination in the US. Changing things is tough because society has these set ideas, and while we've come a long way from the 1800s, change is slow. I think we're making progress though. More women are becoming CEOs and getting accepted in business, and more men are staying home with the kids and it's becoming more okay.  People are starting to see that it doesn't always have to be a certain way. And in fashion, maybe people are listening to their female friends and wives and realizing that guys can know about fashion too. You kind of have to promote these different types of people by showing the good qualities without pushing too hard. If you force it, people resist. 

I think we're in a good place where things are starting to change naturally. I don't know if there's anything else we can do right now besides what's already being done. Change takes time.   

Oh, and by the way, it's not just about gender. People can be discriminated against based on where they're from or their education too. Like, if someone grew up on a farm and their grammar isn't perfect, but they're super smart and work their way up to a CEO position, other guys might look down on them and think they aren't serious because of their grammar. It's like, who knows what they're really saying if they can't speak properly. So yeah, there's discrimination based on a lot of things.

So, basically, they didn't actually make it legal, they just took it off the books as a criminal offense. You know, like a parking ticket instead of jail time.  My understanding is that if you get caught, it's still gonna mess with your job applications and stuff, even if it's not as bad as a full-blown arrest. The thing is, even though it's not a crime anymore, people still worry about those future consequences. But, on the other hand, it costs a lot of money to arrest and process people for marijuana.  It costs a lot to keep them in jail, take them to court, and everything else.   So, for places that are struggling financially, it makes sense that they wouldn't want to decriminalize it, even if it would save them money. Some places just don't want to do it, even if they know it would be good for their budget. But, places like Denver, where people are more open-minded, I think it's totally fine. I bet they're using the money they saved to help people in need.  

It's important because we don't want weed everywhere, you know? There are other reasons why it shouldn't be super easy to get. But the money stuff is a big deal too.

What if it got completely legal? Like cigarettes? Then everyone would be smoking it everywhere, and we'd have people driving high. And even now, it's still kind of taboo in a lot of places. It would just feel weird to have it so open.  


I think alcohol messes with your motor skills worse, but marijuana can really mess with your life in other ways. But they both have bad effects, and everyone reacts differently. Some people can handle it better than others. It's hard to say what's worse because it depends on the person.

Hmmm...this whole Catholic thing, it's a mixed bag, you know?

On one hand, I get why people like them. They've got these strong traditions, things they've been doing for ages. Feels kinda comforting, like you've got roots. But hanging on too tight can be a problem too, gotta be able to bend with the times. 

See, a lot of Catholics I know, they take it seriously, like going to church every week is a must. And the rules?  They're pretty strict about how things are done. Sometimes it feels like they think only *perfect* Catholics belong, and they're not so welcoming to folks who aren't exactly on the same page, or even from different religions.

Take my parents, for example.  My mom was Catholic, my dad was Episcopalian, and the church wouldn't marry them!  Saying you love everyone but then not accepting them? Kinda hypocritical, right? It's like they preach love but then act closed off.

The church tells you to do good things, but sometimes their way of doing things just feels stuck in the past.  

Now, some folks say letting priests marry would be a good idea, but honestly, I don't think it would stop the bad stuff. It's a separate issue, you know?

I mean, people who hurt kids, they'll probably do it no matter what.  Being married doesn't change that.

Hmm... this whole thing about marriage is really tough. I can't say one side is right or wrong, but it's definitely the hardest issue we're facing right now. It's like a balancing act between keeping church and state separate and figuring out what marriage really means.  It's super tricky, you know?  Like, should the government get involved in defining marriage at all? If it's a religious thing, shouldn't it be up to the churches?  Take baptism, for example, no one gets special treatment from the government just because they're baptized. So maybe marriage should just be seen as a civil union, like two people coming together. The government shouldn't care what kind of marriage it is, just that two people are united.  And speaking of different types of marriage, this whole gay marriage thing... it's just two people wanting to be together, right?  If everyone can agree on a solution, shouldn't it become a national law?  But trying to ban gay marriage with a constitutional amendment? That's crazy! It feels like such a big deal to some people, but it doesn't seem like a good reason to change the constitution.

Hmm...growing up in a Christian home, things like homosexuality are kinda confusing for me.  I've got plenty of gay friends, you see? I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, but I think everyone should have the right to do their own thing.  It shouldn't be a big national debate, though.  I feel like each state should decide for themselves whether or not to legalize gay marriage. You know, like some states are more liberal, some are more conservative.  If you live in a state that's okay with gay marriage, well,  that's just how it is there. You kinda chose to live there, right?  I think everyone deserves the same opportunities, whether they're gay or straight. So, let each state make its own call. 

I already kinda said it, but it just feels wrong for someone like Bush, who doesn't live in every state, to ban gay marriage for the whole country. It should be up to each state to decide. I just don't think he should have that much power. Plus, he's leaving office soon anyway. If a different president comes in who wants to lift the ban, it'll just be back and forth. It's better to let each state figure it out themselves. They're the ones who have to live with the decision.

Okay, so let me get this straight. Myspace is like a public bulletin board, right? If you put something on there, anyone can see it, not just your friends.  Even if school officials aren't looking under the school's name, they can still find it from home. 

Think about it, if they're looking at Myspace to keep kids safe, like stopping a school shooting, that seems okay.  Schools have a responsibility to protect students, right?  

But, if they're just snooping around to catch kids doing stuff they shouldn't, like drinking or smoking, that's an invasion of privacy.  It's different when they're trying to prevent something bad from happening. 

It's easier to express yourself in writing, so I guess I could say more about that. Since Myspace is public, if you post something and don't expect to get in trouble, that's kind of silly. Everything you do online can come back to bite you later.

Like, what you do in college could come back to haunt you when you're older. Once something is online, it's out there forever. 

I don't think it's an invasion of privacy to look at Myspace if they have a reason to believe something bad might happen.  It's like when parents drop their kids off at school, they want to know it's a safe place.

My teacher told me that schools have to do things like lock downs and drills to keep everyone safe. They want to be prepared for anything, like a school shooting.

Okay, so, about this war...At first, I was all for it. Nine Eleven really hit me hard—it felt personal. I wanted to fight back, to dish out the same kind of trouble they caused us. Looking back, I think we were too caught up in the emotions. It felt like we rushed into things without a real plan, and it just backfired. 

Now, I'm totally against it. I don't think it accomplished anything. It seems like those people are too busy fighting each other to bother with us. What's the point of us being there if they can't even get along? Honestly,  because of Nine Eleven, I don't really care what happens over there anymore. I just feel like they're all so different from us. They fight and fight, but they can't seem to solve anything on their own.

We went in unprepared. We didn't know what we were walking into, and war over there is unlike anything we've ever seen. They're just brutal, and I don't think they care about improving their country. They just want us out. I think that's fine with me—we should just leave.

Honestly, I think we were all hyped up and angry, more than anything. We weren't thinking clearly about the consequences or how they'd react to us trying to change their whole way of life. It felt like we were just looking for revenge, and President Bush went along with it because the people wanted it.

I get it, though. After Nine Eleven, we couldn't just ignore what happened. We had to do something. But maybe we could have done it differently.  We should have had a better plan, been clearer about our goals, and worked together better. There was no unity, no clear direction. 

I just think we went in with too much emotion and anger, and that's what we created there.  

Maybe we're not the ones to change them. Maybe they'll always be like this. I don't know. I've said enough.
